text.p: Following are some of the main stories in Dutch newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
HET FINANCIEELE DAGBLAD
- Large Dutch banks active on Amsterdam stock exchange plan to restrict bourse's complaints commission's activities. (p1)
- The finance ministry announced on Friday a new 10-year 5.75 percent bond issue. (p1)
- Relatively strong economic growth in the Netherlands had hardly any impact on inflation in 1996. (p1)
- Building concern HBG expects EPS will remain stable this year, after 1996 net rose slightly to Dfl 110 million. (p1)
- Stork subsidiary Fokker Aviation signs provisional agreement with Airbus to participate in new aircraft A3XX. (p1)
- Managers of Germany's Siemens' Dutch unit Siemens Nixdorf Informatiesystemen SNI resign unexpectedly. (p3)
- Publisher Wegener's music TV station The Music Factory TMF gets competition from rival Strengholt's TV Noordzee. (p4)
- A majority of chemicals concern Akzo Nobel's employees in the Netherlands favour a 36-hours working week. (p5)
DE VOLKSKRANT
- Soccer association KNVB and finance ministry work on a new television rights deal. (p1)
- ABN AMRO bank has to testify against Indonesian union leader Pakpahan. (p2)
- Free Record Shop seeks expansion outside the home entertainment sector of video and CD. (p2)
DE TELEGRAAF
- PM Wim Kok eager to extend his premiership by a second term. (p3)
- CasTel telecom, an Edon utility group unit, experiments with glassfibre through gaspipes. (p3)
- FNV threatens RTL 4 with legal action, if a a programme about corruption within the union is broadcast. (p8)
- Fierce cold of the past weeks has disrupted chemical giant DSM's production. (p13)
TROUW
- FNV union chief Lodewijk de Waal plans to talk with South Korean union leaders in Seoul. (p4)
ALGEMEEN DAGBLAD
- A number of tour operators near bankruptcy as a result of a fire in brochures distribution centre. (p1)
- Endemol entertainment claims Dfl 44 million from bankrupt TV- channel Sport 7. (p11)
